name: 2-chlorobenzeneboronic acid
Reason: The basic unit, benzene, has a melting point of 5.5°C. A boronic acid group typically increases the melting point due to the capability of forming boroxine rings and intermolecular hydrogen bonds, which could add approximately +140°C. Chlorine is an electron-withdrawing group that can participate in intermolecular attractions such as dipole-dipole interactions, potentially adding around +30°C. Moreover, the ortho-position of the substituents could contribute to additional hindrance that slightly elevates the melting point, adding about +5°C. Summing these adjustments provides an estimated melting point for 2-chlorobenzeneboronic acid.

name: 2-chlorobenzeneboronic acid
Reason: The basic unit, benzene, has a melting point of 5.5°C. A boronic acid group typically increases the melting point due to the capability of forming boroxine rings and intermolecular hydrogen bonds, which could add approximately +60°C. Chlorine is an electron-withdrawing group that can participate in intermolecular attractions such as dipole-dipole interactions, potentially adding around +20°C to the melting point. The ortho-position of the substituents could contribute to steric hindrance that might slightly elevate the melting point, adding about +2.5°C. Taking these adjustments into account provides an estimated melting point for 2-chlorobenzeneboronic acid.
